Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "Zongzi" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(February 2013)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* ***Zongzi*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 粽子; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *zòngzi*) or simply ***zong*** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 粽; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *zòng*; [Jyutping](/wiki/Jyutping): *zung2*) is a traditional Chinese rice dish made of [glutinous rice](/wiki/Glutinous_rice) stuffed with a range of fillings and wrapped in [bamboo](/wiki/Bamboo) leaves. Fillings can be either sweet, such as [red bean paste](/wiki/Red_bean_paste), or savory, such as [pork belly](/wiki/Pork_belly) or [Chinese sausage](/wiki/Chinese_sausage). The bamboo for wrapping the *zongzi* is generally of the species *[Indocalamus tessellatus](/wiki/Indocalamus_tessellatus)*, although sometimes [reed](/wiki/Common_reed) or other large flat leaves may be used. *Zongzi* are cooked by steaming or boiling. ## Names As it diffused to other regions of Asia over many centuries, *zongzi* became known by various names in different languages and cultures, including *phet htoke* (ဖက်ထုပ်) in [Burmese](/wiki/Burmese_language)-speaking areas (such as [Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar)), *nom chang* in [Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodia), *machang* in [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines), *bacang* in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), *khanom chang* in [Laos](/wiki/Laos), and *ba-chang* in [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand). [Vietnamese cuisine](/wiki/Vietnamese_cuisine) also has a variation on this dish known as *bánh ú tro* or *bánh tro*. In [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), and [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan), *zongzi* is known as *bakcang*, *bacang*, or *zang* (from [Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 肉粽; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *bah-chàng*; lit. 'meat zong', as Hokkien is commonly used among overseas Chinese); Straits Peranakans also know them as the derivative *[kueh](/wiki/Kuih) chang* in their [Malay dialect](/wiki/Baba_Malay). Similarly, *zongzi* is more popularly known as *machang* among [Chinese Filipinos](/wiki/Chinese_Filipino) in the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines). [Japanese cuisine](/wiki/Japanese_cuisine) has leaf-wrapped glutinous rice flour dumplings called *chimaki*. They may be [tetrahedral](/wiki/Tetrahedral), square, rectangular, or long narrow conical in shape. In some areas of the United States, particularly [California](/wiki/California) and [Texas](/wiki/Texas), *zongzi* are often known as "Chinese *[tamales](/wiki/Tamales)*". In [Mauritius](/wiki/Mauritius), *zongzi* (typically called *zong*), is a traditional dish which continues to be eaten by the [Sino-Mauritian](/wiki/Mauritians_of_Chinese_origin) and by the [Overseas Chinese](/wiki/Overseas_Chinese) communities. It is especially eaten on the [Dragon Boat Festival](/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival), a traditional festive event, to commemorate the death of [Qu Yuan](/wiki/Qu_Yuan). ## Popular origin myths What has become established popular belief amongst the Chinese is that *zongzi* has since the days of yore been a food-offering to commemorate the death of [Qu Yuan](/wiki/Qu_Yuan), a famous [poet](/wiki/Chinese_poet) from the [kingdom of Chu](/wiki/Chu_(state)) who lived during the [Warring States period](/wiki/Warring_States_period). Known for his patriotism, Qu Yuan tried to counsel his king to no avail, and drowned himself in the [Miluo River](/wiki/Miluo_River) in 278 BC.[a] The Chinese people were grateful for Qu Yuan's talent and loyalty to serve the country. They cast rice dumplings into the Miluo River on the day when Qu Yuan was thrown into the river every year, hoping that the fish in the river would eat the rice dumplings without harming Qu Yuan's body. Qu Yuan died in 278 BC, but the earliest known documented association between him and the *zong* dumplings occurs much later, in the mid 5th century ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 世说新语; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Shìshuō Xīnyǔ*, or *[A New Account of the Tales of the World](/wiki/A_New_Account_of_the_Tales_of_the_World)*), And a widely observed popular cult around him did not develop until the 6th century AD, as far as can be substantiated by evidence. But by the 6th century, sources attest to the offering of *zongzi* on the [Double Fifth](/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival) Festival (5th day of the 5th month of the lunar calendar) being connected with the figure of Qu Yuan. As for the origin myth, a fable recounts that the people commemorated the drowning death of Qu Yuan on the [Double Fifth](/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival) day by casting rice stuffed in bamboo tubes; but the practice changed in the early [Eastern Han](/wiki/Eastern_Han) dynasty (1st century AD),[b] when the ghost of Qu Yuan appeared in a dream to a man named Ou Hui ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 區回, 歐回) and instructed him to seal the rice packet with [chinaberry](/wiki/Melia_azedarach) (or *Melia*) leaves and bind it with colored string, to repel the dragons (*[jiaolong](/wiki/Jiaolong)*) that would otherwise consume them. However, this fable is not attested in contemporary (Han period) literature, and only known to be recorded centuries later in Wu Jun [zh] (呉均; *Wu chün*, d. 520)'s *Xu Qixieji* (『續齊諧記』; **Hsü-ch'ih-hsieh-chih**). Also, Qu Yuan had (dubiously, by "folklore" or by common belief) become connected with the boat races held on the Double Fifth, datable by another 6th century source. 《荊楚歲時記》(6th c.), under the "Fifth Day of the Fifth Month" heading. Modern media has printed a version of the legend which says that the locals had rushed out in [dragonboats](/wiki/Dragonboat) to try retrieve his body and threw packets of rice into the river to distract the fish from eating the poet's body. ## History *Zongzi* (sticky rice dumplings) are traditionally eaten during the [Duanwu Festival](/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival) (Double Fifth Festival) which falls on the fifth day of the fifth month of the [Chinese lunisolar calendar](/wiki/Chinese_lunisolar_calendar), and commonly known as the "Dragon Boat Festival" in English. The festival falls each year on a day in late-May to mid-June in the International calendar. The practice of eating *zongzi* on the Double Fifth or [summer solstice](/wiki/Summer_solstice) is concretely documented in literature from around the late Han (2nd–3rd centuries).[c] At the end of the [Eastern Han dynasty](/wiki/Eastern_Han_dynasty), people made *zong*, also called *jiao shu*, lit. "horned/angled millet") by wrapping [sticky rice](/wiki/Sticky_rice) with the leaves of the *[Zizania latifolia](/wiki/Zizania_latifolia)* plant ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 菰; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *gu*, a sort of wild rice) and boiling them in [lye](/wiki/Lye) (grass-and-[wood ash](/wiki/Wood_ash) water). The name *jiao shu* may imply "ox-horn shape", or cone-shape. That the *zong* or *ziao shu* prepared in this way was eaten on the occasion of the Double Fifth (Duanwu) is documented in works as early as the *[Fengsu Tongyi](/wiki/Fengsu_Tongyi)*, AD 195). These festive rice dumplings are also similarly described in General [Zhou Chu](/wiki/Zhou_Chu) (236–297)'s *Fengtu Ji*, "Record of Local Folkways" Various sources claim that this *Fengtu Ji* contains the first documented reference regarding *zongzi*, even though it dates somewhat later than the *Fengsu Tongyi*. In the [Jin dynasty](/wiki/Jin_dynasty_(266%E2%80%93420)) (晋, AD 266–420), *zongzi* was officially a [Dragon Boat Festival](/wiki/Dragon_Boat_Festival) food. Anecdotally, an official called Lu Xun [zh] from the Jin dynasty once sent *zongzi* which used *yizhiren* [zh] ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 益智仁, the [fruit](/wiki/Fruit) of *[Alpinia](/wiki/Alpinia) oxyphylla* or sharp leaf [galangal](/wiki/Galangal)) as additional filling; this type of dumpling was then dubbed *yizhi zong* ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 益智粽, literally "dumplings to increase wisdom"). Later in the [Northern and Southern dynasties](/wiki/Northern_and_Southern_dynasties), mixed *zongzi* appeared, the rice was filled with fillings such as meat, chestnuts, [jujubes](/wiki/Jujube), red beans, and they were exchanged as gifts to relatives and friends. In the 6th century ([Sui](/wiki/Sui_dynasty) to early [Tang dynasty](/wiki/Tang_dynasty)), the dumpling is also being referred to as "tubular *zong*" ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 筒糉/筒粽; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *tongzong*), and they were being made by being packed inside "young bamboo" tubes.[d] The 6th century source for this states that the dumplings were eaten on the Summer Solstice, (instead of the Double Fifth). In the [Tang dynasty](/wiki/Tang_dynasty), the shape of *zongzi* appeared conical and diamond-shaped, and the rice which was used to make *zongzi* was as white as jade. *Datang zongzi* (i.e. the *zongzi* eaten in Tang Imperial period) was also recorded in some [classical-era](/wiki/Classical_Japan) [Japanese literature](/wiki/Japanese_literature), which was [heavily influenced by Tang Chinese culture](/wiki/Japanese_missions_to_Tang_China). In the [Northern Song](/wiki/Northern_Song_(960%E2%80%931127)) dynasty period, the "New augmentation to the *[Shuowen Jiezi](/wiki/Shuowen_Jiezi)*" ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 説文新附; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Shouwen xinfu*) glossed *zong* as rice with reed leaves wrapped around it.[e] *Mijiian Zong* (zongzi with [glacé fruit](/wiki/Candied_fruit)) was also popular in the Song dynasty. Also during the Song dynasty, there were many [preserved fruit](/wiki/Preserved_fruit) *zongzi*. At this time also appeared a [pavilion](/wiki/Chinese_pavilion) filled with *zongzi* for advertising, which showed that eating *zongzi* in the Song dynasty had been very fashionable. In the [Yuan](/wiki/Yuan_dynasty) and [Ming](/wiki/Ming_dynasty) dynasties, the wrapping material had changed from *gu* (wild rice) leaf to *ruo* (箬; the *[Indocalamus tessellatus](/wiki/Indocalamus_tessellatus)* bamboo) leaf, and then to reed leaves,[*dubious – discuss*] and filled with materials like [bean paste](/wiki/Sweet_bean_paste), [pine nut kernel](/wiki/Pine_nut), [pork](/wiki/Pork), [walnut](/wiki/Walnut), [jujube](/wiki/Jujube), and so on. The varieties of *zongzi* were more diverse. During the Ming and [Qing dynasties](/wiki/Qing_dynasties), *zongzi* became auspicious food. At that time, scholars who took the [imperial examinations](/wiki/Imperial_examination) would eat "pen *zongzi*", which was specially given to them at home, before going to the examination hall. Because it looked long and thin like a [writing brush](/wiki/Writing_brush), the pronunciation of "pen *zongzi*" is similar to the Chinese word for "pass", which was for good omen.[*failed verification*] [Ham](/wiki/Ham) *zongzi* appeared in the Qing dynasty.[*better source needed*] Every year in early May of the lunar calendar, the Chinese people still soak glutinous rice, wash the leaves and wrap up *zongzi*. ## Description The shapes of *zongzi* vary, and range from being approximately [tetrahedral](/wiki/Tetrahedra) in southern China to an elongated [cone](/wiki/Cone) in northern China. In the [Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall](/wiki/Chiang_Kai-shek_Memorial_Hall) in Taipei, plastic mock-ups of rectangular *zongzi* are displayed as an example of the *zongzi* eaten by Chiang Kai-shek.[*citation needed*] Wrapping *zongzi* neatly is a skill that is passed down through [families](/wiki/Family), as are the recipes. Making zongzi is traditionally a family event in which everyone helps out. While traditional *zongzi* are wrapped in bamboo leaves, the leaves of [lotus](/wiki/Nelumbo_nucifera), [reed](/wiki/Reed_(plant)), [maize](/wiki/Maize), [banana](/wiki/Banana), [canna](/wiki/Canna_(plant)), [shell ginger](/wiki/Alpinia_zerumbet), and [pandan](/wiki/Pandanus) sometimes are used as substitutes in other countries. Each kind of leaf imparts its own unique aroma and flavor to the rice. The fillings used for *zongzi* vary from region to region, but the [rice](/wiki/Rice) used is almost always [glutinous rice](/wiki/Glutinous_rice) (also called "sticky rice" or "sweet rice"). Depending on the region, the rice may be lightly precooked by [stir-frying](/wiki/Stir-frying) or soaked in water before using. In the north, fillings are mostly red bean paste and [tapioca](/wiki/Tapioca) or [taro](/wiki/Taro). Northern style *zongzi* tend to be sweet and dessert-like. In the northern region of China, *zongzi* filled with [jujubes](/wiki/Jujube) are popular. Southern-style *zongzi*, however, tend to be more savoury or salty. Fillings of Southern-style *zongzi* include ham, salted duck egg, [pork belly](/wiki/Pork_belly), taro, shredded pork or chicken, Chinese sausage, pork fat, and [shiitake mushrooms](/wiki/Shiitake). However, as the variations of *zongzi* styles have traveled and become mixed, today one can find all kinds of them at traditional markets, and their types are not confined to which side of the [Yellow River](/wiki/Yellow_River) they originated from. *Zongzi* need to be [steamed](/wiki/Steaming) or [boiled](/wiki/Boiling) for several hours depending on how the rice is prepared prior to being added, along with the fillings. With the advent of modern food processing, pre-cooked *zongzi* (usually in [vacuum packs](/wiki/Vacuum_pack) or [frozen](/wiki/Frozen_food)) are now available. ### Fillings Sweet: - [White sugar](/wiki/White_sugar) (mixed into rice, frequently present) - [Mung beans](/wiki/Mung_bean), split and dehulled - [Red bean paste](/wiki/Red_bean_paste) - Lotus seed - [Yam](/wiki/Yam_(vegetable)) - [Jujube](/wiki/Jujube) Salty or savory: - [Soy sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce) (mixed into rice, almost always present) - [Chinese sausage](/wiki/Chinese_sausage) - Mushrooms, preferably [xiang gu](/wiki/Shiitake) - [Salted duck egg](/wiki/Salted_duck_egg) yolks, or hard-boiled eggs - Pork, such as ham and/or pork belly - *[Conpoy](/wiki/Conpoy)* (dried scallops) - [Red-cooked](/wiki/Red_cooking) meats - [Chicken](/wiki/Chicken_(food)) Either or neutral: - Nuts - [Water chestnuts](/wiki/Water_chestnut) - Cooked [peanuts](/wiki/Peanut) - Vegetables - Meat Floss ## Variations ### Mainland China - *Jiaxing zongzi* (嘉興粽子): This is a kind of *zongzi* famous in mainland China and named after the city [Jiaxing](/wiki/Jiaxing), Zhejiang. Typically savory with the rice mixed with soy sauce and having pork, chestnut and salted duck egg yolk as its filling, but sweet ones with [mung bean](/wiki/Mung_bean) or red bean filling also exist. - *Jia zong* (假粽): Instead of glutinous rice, balls of glutinous rice flour (so no individual grains of rice are discernible) are used to enclose the fillings of the *zongzi*. These "fake *zong*" are typically smaller than most and are much stickier. - *Jianshui zong* (碱水粽): These "alkaline water *zong*" are typically eaten as a dessert item rather than as part of the main meal. The glutinous rice is treated with *jianzongshui* (碱粽水, alkali[ne] *zongzi* water, aqueous [sodium carbonate](/wiki/Sodium_carbonate) or [potassium carbonate](/wiki/Potassium_carbonate)), giving them their distinctive yellow color. *Jianshui zong* typically contain either no filling or are filled with a sweet mixture, such as [sweet bean paste](/wiki/Sweet_bean_paste). Sometimes, a certain redwood sliver ([蘇木](/wiki/Biancaea_sappan)) is inserted for color and flavor. They are often eaten with sugar or light syrup. - *Cantonese jung* (廣東糉): This is representative of the southern variety of *zongzi*, usually consisting of marinated meat, such as pork belly, and duck, with other ingredients like mung bean paste, mushrooms, dried scallops, and salted egg yolk. Cantonese *jung* are small, the front is square, back has a raised sharp angle, shaped like an awl.[*further explanation needed*] - *[Chiu Chou](/wiki/Chaozhou) jung* (潮州粽): This is a variation of Cantonese *jung* with red bean paste, pork belly, chestnut, mushroom, and dried shrimp, in a triangular prism. - *[Banlam](/wiki/Minnan_region) zang* (閩南粽): [Xiamen](/wiki/Xiamen), [Quanzhou](/wiki/Quanzhou) area is very famous for its pork rice dumplings, made with braised pork with pork belly, plus mushrooms, shrimp, and so on. - *[Sichuan](/wiki/Sichuan) zong* (四川粽): Sichuan people like to eat spicy and "tingly-numbing" (麻) sense food, so they make spicy rice dumplings. They add [Sichuan peppercorns](/wiki/Sichuan_peppercorn), [chili powder](/wiki/Chili_powder), Sichuan salt, and a little preserved pork, wrapped into four-cornered dumplings. Cooked and then roasted, it tastes tender and flavorful. - *[Beijing](/wiki/Beijing) zong* (北京粽): The Beijing *zong* are sweet and often eaten cold. Common fillings include red dates and bean paste, as well as preserved fruit. - *[Shanxi](/wiki/Shanxi) zong* (山西粽): In Shanxi, zongzi are often made with yellow glutinous millet or sticky yellow rice instead of the more commonly used white glutinous rice. Typical fillings include red dates or sweetened red beans. The resulting texture is notably chewy and dense, offering a distinctively hearty flavor. ### Taiwan - Taiwanese *zongzi* are regionally split by the process of cooking rather than filling. - Northern Taiwanese *zongzi* (北部粽) are wrapped with husks of *[Phyllostachys](/wiki/Phyllostachys) makinoi* bamboo (桂竹籜), then steamed. - Southern Taiwanese *zongzi* (南部粽) are wrapped with leaves of *[Bambusa oldhamii](/wiki/Bambusa_oldhamii)* (麻竹葉), then boiled. - The filling is classified simply by eating habits: - Vegetarian *zongzi* in Taiwan is made with dry peanut flakes. - The meat-filled *zongzi* in Taiwan is made with fresh pork, chicken, duck, egg yolk, mushroom, dried shrimps, or fried scallions. ### Japan - Japanese *chimaki* are very similar to the Chinese versions using various species of the bamboo *[Sasa](/wiki/Sasa_(plant))* but possibly with different fillings, and are divided into savory and sweet types. - A special sweet *chimaki* is eaten on [Children's Day](/wiki/Children%27s_Day_(Japan)) (*kodomo no hi*, May 5), and is identifiable by its long narrow conical shape. ### Mauritius - Sweet *zong* is a *zongzi* made of a plain rice (i.e. without any fillings) which is eaten with crushed [peanut](/wiki/Peanut) in sugar. - Salty *zong* contains meat, beans and other fillings in the rice. ### Malaysia and Singapore - *[Nyonya](/wiki/Nyonya) chang* (娘惹粽): A specialty of [Peranakan cuisine](/wiki/Peranakan_cuisine), these *zongzi* are made similarly to those from southern China. However, [pandan leaves](/wiki/Pandanus_amaryllifolius) are often used, in addition to bamboo leaves, for the wrapping while minced pork with candied [winter melon](/wiki/Winter_melon), a spice mix, and sometimes ground roasted peanuts are used as the fillings. As with a common practice found in Peranakan pastries, part of the rice on these *zongzi* are often dyed blue with the extract from [blue pea flower](/wiki/Clitoria_ternatea) to add to the aesthetic. ## Museum The Jiaxing Zongzi Culture Museum in [Jiaxing, China](/wiki/Jiaxing,_China) has exhibits of the cultural history and various styles of *zongzi*. ## Gallery - Variations of zongzi - Food portal - China portal - Taiwan portal - [Bánh lá](/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_l%C3%A1) - [Bánh chưng](/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_ch%C6%B0ng) - [Bánh tét](/wiki/B%C3%A1nh_t%C3%A9t) - [Lo mai gai](/wiki/Lo_mai_gai), or lotus leaf wrap - [Chinese sticky rice](/wiki/Chinese_sticky_rice) - [Corunda](/wiki/Corunda) - [Chunga pitha](/wiki/Chunga_pitha) - [Ketupat](/wiki/Ketupat) - [Lontong](/wiki/Lontong) - [Onigiri](/wiki/Onigiri) - [Suman](/wiki/Suman_(food)) - [Salted duck egg](/wiki/Salted_duck_egg), another food eaten in the Dragon Boat Festival - [Tamale](/wiki/Tamale), another food wrapped in leaves and steamed ## Explanatory notes CitationsBibliography - Authentic Zongzi Recipe
title: Zongzi
